contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox language |name=Omagua |nativename= |ethnicity=[[Omagua people|Omagua]] |states=[[Perú]], perhaps [[Brazil]] |extinct=by 2012 |date= |ref=e17 |speakers=unknown number in Brazil |familycolor=American |fam1=[[Tupian languages|Tupian]] |fam2=[[Tupi–Guarani languages|Tupi–Guarani]] |fam3=Tupi (Subgroup III) |fam4=[[Cocama language|Cocama]] |iso3=omg }} '''Omagua''', or ''Omáwa'', is a dialect of [[Cocoma language|Cocoma]] spoken by two [[Omaguas|Omagua]] people,{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}} both of whom are over eighty, who live near [[Iquitos]], [[Peru]]. It was also at one time spoken in western [[Brazil]]. It is now widely understood to be a Creole language which was lexified by a Tupi-Guarani language.{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Omagua Dialect}} [[Category:Tupi–Guarani languages]] [[Category:Languages of Peru]] [[Category:Languages of Brazil]] [[Category:Endangered languages]] {{lang-stub}}
